qas.question: What types of human knowledge did Hume say there are?

answers.text: relations of ideas and matters of fact

qas.question: What type of human knowledge is math?
What type of human knowledge is observing the world?
What type of human knowledge is "the sun rises in the East"?
Where did Hume say people's ideas come from?
How many categories did Kant divide the world into?
What would the incorrect phrase "the sun rises in the west" be?

plausible_answers.text: To remember or to imagine such impressions is to have an "idea"

qas.question: Why are sensations considered copies of ideas?

plausible_answers.text: all of human knowledge into two categories

context: Hume divided <b8_0>all of human knowledge into <b5_0>two<b5_0/> categories<b8_0/>: <a0_0><a1_0>relations of ideas<a1_0/> and <a2_0><a3_0><b6_0>matters of fact<b6_0/><a3_0/><a2_0/><a0_0/> (see also Kant's analytic-synthetic distinction). Mathematical and logical propositions (e.g. "that the square of the hypotenuse is equal to the sum of the squares of the two sides") are examples of the first, while propositions involving some contingent observation of the world (e.g. "the sun rises in the East") are examples of the second. All of people's "ideas", in turn, are derived from <a4_0>their "impressions"<a4_0/>. For Hume, an "impression" corresponds roughly with what we call a sensation. <b7_0>To remember or to imagine such impressions is to have an "idea"<b7_0/>. Ideas are therefore the faint copies of sensations.
